qas.question: What public entity of learning is often target of civil disobedience?
Who believed that civil disobedience should only be used against governmental entities?
What two groups do trade unions think civil disobedience is justified against?

plausible_answers.text: if it reflects "a larger challenge to the legal system that permits those decisions to be taken"

qas.question: When is civil disobedience justified against certain groups according to trade unions?

plausible_answers.text: to breaches of law in protest

qas.question: In what other way can disobedience be applied to international organizations and governments?
When do banks believe civil disobedience is justified?

context: Some theories of civil disobedience hold that civil disobedience is only justified against governmental entities. Brownlee argues that disobedience in opposition to the decisions of non-governmental agencies such as trade unions, banks, and private universities can be justified if it reflects "a larger challenge to the legal system that permits those decisions to be taken". The same principle, she argues, applies to breaches of law in protest against international organizations and foreign governments.
